title: Five ways it’s about to get even worse for Rachel Reeves
description: Economists believe the Chancellor will need to find at least £20bn in her November Budget
content:
Tony Blair swept into Downing Street to the sound of Things Can Only Get Better by D:ream. For Rachel Reeves, a rewrite may be required – Things Can Only Get Worse.

The Chancellor has set the clock ticking on her second Budget, announcing that it will be held on Nov 26.

Reeves is already under pressure, with bond yields rising and the pound weakening. Speculation is rife over which taxes will have to go up to fill yet another black hole. As things stand, economists believe she will need to find £20bn or more to restore the public finances to health.

The Chancellor will be hoping that things will improve between now and the Budget.

Perhaps the turmoil in financial markets will ebb. Perhaps the Government will find some new productivity-boosting wheeze to convince the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) to upgrade its growth forecasts.

Yet on current trends, things look more likely to get worse than better. Here are five reasons why the Chancellor should be wary.

1. Bond yields are unlikely to improve

Interest rates on 30-year UK bonds are currently at highs not seen since 1998, meaning the Government must pay handsomely for the borrowing it sorely needs.

This is not like 2022, when a spike in bond yields in the wake of the mini-Budget brought down Liz Truss’s government.

Then, borrowing costs subsided after Truss changed tack and, eventually, resigned.

This time around, other nations are also seeing steady rises in bond yields, indicating that debt is getting more expensive globally. It suggests there there is little room for any serious relief in the weeks to come.
summary: UK Chancellor, Rachel Reeves, is under pressure due to rising bond yields and a weakening pound, and economists believe she will need to find £20bn or more to restore the public finances. Interest rates on 30-year UK bonds are currently at highs not seen since 1998, meaning the government will have to pay significantly for the borrowing it desperately needs. However, current trends suggest that debt is becoming more expensive globally.
shortSummary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves faces increasing pressure due to rising bond yields, a weakening pound, and potential tax increases to restore public finances.
argos_summary: Rachel Reeves faces mounting pressure ahead of her November Budget as bond yields hit 1998 highs and the pound weakens, forcing the government to raise at least £20 bn to shore up public finances. Global yield increases suggest limited relief for borrowing costs, while market turmoil and uncertain growth forecasts add to the challenge. The Chancellor must navigate these headwinds to avoid worsening fiscal conditions.
